batch.name: Class 11 - Chapter 10: Cell Cycle and Cell Division

questions.question: The cell cycle was first described by:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, Howard and Pelc (1953) first described the cell cycle. They identified the different phases of the cell cycle using radioactive labelling techniques.

questions.question: DNA replication occurs during which phase of the cell cycle?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, DNA replication occurs during the S (Synthesis) phase of interphase. During this phase, the amount of DNA per cell doubles, but the chromosome number remains the same.

questions.question: Which phase of the cell cycle is the longest?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the G1 phase (Gap 1 or first growth phase) is typically the longest phase of the cell cycle. During G1, the cell is metabolically active and grows but does not replicate its DNA.

questions.question: Cells that do not divide further exit G1 and enter:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, cells that do not divide further exit the G1 phase and enter an inactive stage called the G0 phase (quiescent phase). These cells remain metabolically active but no longer proliferate (e.g., mature neurons).

questions.question: During which phase of mitosis do chromosomes align at the equatorial plate?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during metaphase, chromosomes are aligned at the equatorial plate (metaphase plate). The centromeres of all chromosomes lie on the metaphase plate, with spindle fibres attached to the kinetochores.

questions.question: The centromere splits during which phase of mitosis?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during anaphase, each centromere splits (divides), allowing the two sister chromatids to separate and move to opposite poles of the cell. This is driven by shortening of spindle fibres.

questions.question: Cytokinesis in plant cells occurs by:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, cytokinesis in plant cells occurs by formation of a cell plate. Vesicles from the Golgi apparatus fuse at the centre of the cell to form the cell plate, which grows outward to divide the cell.

questions.question: Cytokinesis in animal cells occurs by:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, cytokinesis in animal cells occurs by the formation of a cleavage furrow. The plasma membrane constricts inward at the centre of the cell, eventually pinching the cell into two daughter cells.

questions.question: Crossing over occurs during which stage of meiosis?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, crossing over (recombination) occurs during the pachytene stage of prophase I. It involves the exchange of genetic material between non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes at chiasmata.

questions.question: Bivalent formation (synapsis) occurs during which stage of prophase I?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, synapsis (pairing of homologous chromosomes) occurs during zygotene stage of prophase I. The paired chromosomes are called bivalents or tetrads (as each bivalent has 4 chromatids).

questions.question: Chiasmata become visible during which stage of prophase I?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, chiasmata (X-shaped structures where crossing over occurred) become visible during the diplotene stage. During this stage, the synaptonemal complex dissolves and the homologous chromosomes begin to separate, but remain attached at chiasmata.

questions.question: Terminalization of chiasmata occurs during:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during diakinesis (the final stage of prophase I), terminalization of chiasmata occurs. The chiasmata move towards the ends (termini) of the chromosomes. The nuclear membrane and nucleolus also disappear during this stage.

questions.question: How many daughter cells are produced at the end of meiosis?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, meiosis involves two successive divisions (meiosis I and meiosis II) resulting in four haploid daughter cells from one diploid parent cell. The chromosome number is halved.

questions.question: During which phase of mitosis does the nuclear envelope reappear?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during telophase, the nuclear envelope reforms around the group of chromosomes at each pole. The chromosomes decondense, and the nucleolus reappears. These events are essentially the reverse of prophase.

questions.question: The synaptonemal complex is formed during:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the synaptonemal complex is formed during zygotene. It is a protein-rich structure that holds the homologous chromosomes together during synapsis. It dissolves during diplotene.

questions.question: In which type of cell division is the chromosome number reduced to half?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, meiosis I is the reductional division where the chromosome number is reduced to half. Homologous chromosomes separate during anaphase I. Meiosis II is equational (like mitosis) where sister chromatids separate.

questions.question: During prophase of mitosis, the chromosomes:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during prophase, the chromatin condenses into visible chromosomes. Each chromosome consists of two sister chromatids joined at the centromere. The nuclear envelope begins to break down and the centrioles move to opposite poles.

questions.question: In the G2 phase of the cell cycle, the cell:
options: B) Prepares for mitosis by synthesising proteins
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during G2 (Gap 2) phase, the cell prepares for mitosis. Proteins needed for cell division, such as tubulins for spindle formation, are synthesised during this phase.

questions.question: Which of the following is the significance of mitosis?
options: C) Growth and repair of tissues
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the significance of mitosis includes growth, repair, and regeneration of tissues. It produces genetically identical daughter cells and maintains the chromosome number. It does NOT produce genetic variation or reduce chromosome number.

questions.question: The best stage to count the number of chromosomes in a cell is:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, metaphase is the best stage for studying chromosomes because they are maximally condensed, clearly visible, and aligned at the metaphase plate, making counting and morphological study easiest.

questions.question: During leptotene of prophase I, chromosomes appear as:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during leptotene (the first stage of prophase I), chromosomes become visible as long, thin threads (lepto = thin, tene = thread). Compaction of chromosomes continues throughout prophase I.

questions.question: The spindle fibres attach to the chromosomes at the:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, spindle fibres attach to the chromosomes at the kinetochore, which is a disc-shaped protein structure located on the centromere. Each chromosome has two kinetochores, one on each sister chromatid.

questions.question: If a human cell has 46 chromosomes, after S phase the DNA content will be:
options: D) Remains at 46 chromosomes but DNA content doubles
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during S phase, DNA replication occurs so the DNA content doubles. However, the chromosome number remains the same (46) because each chromosome now consists of two sister chromatids joined at the centromere.

questions.question: Meiosis II is similar to mitosis because:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, meiosis II is similar to mitosis (equational division) because sister chromatids separate during anaphase II, just as they do during anaphase of mitosis. There is no reduction in chromosome number during meiosis II.

questions.question: Interkinesis is the stage between:
options: B) Meiosis I and meiosis II
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, interkinesis is the short interval between meiosis I and meiosis II. It is generally short-lived and there is NO DNA replication during interkinesis.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a significance of meiosis?
options: B) Maintains chromosome number across generations
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, meiosis produces genetically diverse (NOT identical) cells due to crossing over and independent assortment. Its significance includes genetic variation, maintaining chromosome number across generations, and formation of gametes.

questions.question: During anaphase I of meiosis, what separates?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during anaphase I, homologous chromosomes separate and move to opposite poles (reductional division). Sister chromatids remain attached at the centromere. Sister chromatid separation occurs during anaphase II.

questions.question: A cell with 20 chromosomes undergoes mitosis. How many chromosomes will be in each daughter cell?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, mitosis is an equational division that maintains the chromosome number. Each daughter cell will have the same number of chromosomes as the parent cell, which is 20.

questions.question: In meiosis, the number of DNA replications and cell divisions respectively are:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, in meiosis there is only ONE round of DNA replication (during the S phase before meiosis I) but TWO successive cell divisions (meiosis I and meiosis II), resulting in four haploid cells.

questions.question: Which of the following events occurs during the G1 phase?
options: C) Cell growth and protein synthesis
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during the G1 phase, the cell grows in size and synthesises RNA and proteins needed for DNA synthesis and cell division. The cell is metabolically active during this phase.

questions.question: The shortest phase of mitosis is:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, anaphase is the shortest phase of mitosis. During this phase, the centromeres split and chromatids move rapidly to opposite poles, making it a relatively brief event.

questions.question: Colchicine prevents cell division by:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, colchicine is a chemical that prevents the assembly of spindle fibres by inhibiting tubulin polymerisation into microtubules. Without spindle fibres, chromosomes cannot segregate, and cell division is arrested at metaphase.

questions.question: During which substage of prophase I do homologous chromosomes begin to separate?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during diplotene, the synaptonemal complex dissolves and the homologous chromosomes begin to separate (desynapsis). However, they remain connected at the points of crossing over (chiasmata).

questions.question: A recombinase enzyme that facilitates crossing over is called:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the enzyme recombinase (RecA in prokaryotes, Rad51/Dmc1 in eukaryotes) facilitates crossing over by catalysing the exchange of genetic material between non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes during pachytene.

questions.question: In a yeast cell, the cell cycle is completed in approximately:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the cell cycle duration varies in different organisms. In yeast, it takes approximately 90 minutes. In human cells, the cell cycle lasts about 24 hours.

questions.question: The longest phase of the cell cycle in a typical human cell is:
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, interphase (comprising G1, S, and G2 phases) is the longest part of the cell cycle, occupying about 95% of the total cell cycle time. In a 24-hour human cell cycle, interphase lasts about 23 hours and M phase about 1 hour.

questions.question: Which type of division results in genetic variation in organisms?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, meiosis introduces genetic variation through two mechanisms: (1) crossing over during pachytene of prophase I, and (2) random assortment of homologous chromosomes during anaphase I. This variation is important for evolution.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Meiosis I is called reductional division.
Reason (R): During meiosis I, homologous chromosomes separate, reducing the chromosome number to half.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, meiosis I is called reductional division because homologous chromosomes separate during anaphase I, reducing the chromosome number from diploid (2n) to haploid (n). This is the reason it is called reductional.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Crossing over leads to genetic variation.
Reason (R): Crossing over involves exchange of genetic material between non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, crossing over leads to genetic variation by exchanging segments of DNA between non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes during pachytene. This creates new combinations of genes not present in either parent chromosome.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Interphase is not a resting phase.
Reason (R): During interphase, the cell undergoes active metabolic activity including DNA replication and protein synthesis.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, interphase is often called the 'resting phase' but this is a misnomer. The cell is highly active during interphase, undergoing DNA replication (S phase), RNA and protein synthesis, cell growth, and organelle duplication.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Mitosis maintains the same chromosome number in daughter cells.
Reason (R): In mitosis, sister chromatids separate during anaphase.
options: C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, mitosis is an equational division that maintains chromosome number because sister chromatids (formed during S phase) separate during anaphase, giving each daughter cell the same number of chromosomes as the parent cell.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): DNA replication does not occur between meiosis I and meiosis II.
Reason (R): The interkinesis between meiosis I and II is a short-lived phase.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, both statements are true. DNA replication does not occur during interkinesis, and interkinesis is short-lived. However, the short duration is not the reason for lack of DNA replication; it is because the cell is already prepared for the second division.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Colchicine is used to obtain polyploid plants.
Reason (R): Colchicine inhibits spindle formation, preventing chromosome segregation.
options: D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, colchicine inhibits spindle fibre formation by preventing tubulin polymerisation. Without spindle fibres, chromosomes cannot segregate to daughter cells, resulting in a cell with double the chromosome number (polyploidy).

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Mature neurons and red blood cells do not divide.
Reason (R): They are in the G0 phase of the cell cycle.
options: D) A is false but R is true
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, cells like mature neurons exit the cell cycle and enter G0 (quiescent phase). They remain metabolically active but no longer proliferate. This G0 state explains why they do not divide.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Cytokinesis in plant cells differs from that in animal cells.
Reason (R): Plant cells have a rigid cell wall that cannot be constricted inward.
options: C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, cytokinesis differs in plant and animal cells. Plant cells form a cell plate from the centre outward because the rigid cell wall prevents the formation of a cleavage furrow. Animal cells, lacking a rigid wall, divide by cleavage furrow formation.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): The number of chromosomes at the end of meiosis II is haploid.
Reason (R): Meiosis II involves separation of sister chromatids without DNA replication.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the haploid number at the end of meiosis II is actually established during meiosis I (reductional division). Meiosis II is equational (like mitosis) where sister chromatids separate. Both statements are true but the haploid number results from meiosis I, not meiosis II.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Meiosis is important for maintaining chromosome number across generations.
Reason (R): Without meiosis, the chromosome number would double with each generation after fertilisation.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, meiosis reduces the chromosome number to half in gametes (n). When two haploid gametes fuse during fertilisation, the diploid number (2n) is restored. Without meiosis, each generation would have double the chromosomes.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Prophase is the longest phase of mitosis.
Reason (R): During prophase, chromatin condenses, nuclear envelope disassembles, and spindle forms.
options: A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
C) A is true but R is false
D) A is false but R is true
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, prophase is the longest phase of mitosis because many complex events occur: chromatin condensation, nuclear envelope breakdown, nucleolus disappearance, centriole migration, and spindle formation. These numerous events require more time.

questions.question:
Assertion (A): Metaphase is the best stage for chromosome counting.
Reason (R): During metaphase, chromosomes are at their maximum condensation and are aligned at the equator.
options: B) Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
A) Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
D) A is false but R is true
C) A is true but R is false
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, metaphase is ideal for chromosome counting because chromosomes reach maximum condensation (most compact), making them clearly visible, and they are aligned in a single plane (metaphase plate), making them easy to count.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about the cell cycle are correct?
(i) The cell cycle consists of interphase and M phase
(ii) Interphase includes G1, S, and G2 phases
(iii) DNA replication occurs during G2 phase
(iv) M phase includes karyokinesis and cytokinesis
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the cell cycle consists of interphase (G1+S+G2) and M phase (mitosis + cytokinesis). DNA replication occurs during S phase, NOT G2 phase. Statement (iii) is incorrect.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about prophase I of meiosis:
(i) Leptotene - chromosomes appear as thin threads
(ii) Zygotene - synapsis occurs
(iii) Pachytene - crossing over occurs
(iv) Diplotene - synapsis begins
Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Statement (iv) is incorrect; synapsis begins during zygotene, not diplotene. During diplotene, the homologous chromosomes begin to separate (desynapsis) and chiasmata become visible.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about mitosis are INCORRECT?
(i) It results in two genetically identical daughter cells
(ii) It leads to genetic variation
(iii) It occurs in somatic cells
(iv) It involves crossing over
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, statements (ii) and (iv) are incorrect about mitosis. Mitosis does NOT lead to genetic variation and does NOT involve crossing over. These are features of meiosis. Mitosis produces genetically identical cells and occurs in somatic cells.

questions.question:
Read the following statements about anaphase:
(i) In anaphase of mitosis, sister chromatids separate
(ii) In anaphase I, homologous chromosomes separate
(iii) In anaphase II, homologous chromosomes separate
(iv) Anaphase is the shortest phase of mitosis
How many are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are correct = 3. Statement (iii) is incorrect; in anaphase II, sister chromatids separate (like mitosis), NOT homologous chromosomes. Homologous separation occurs only in anaphase I.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about the significance of meiosis:
(i) It maintains chromosome number across generations
(ii) It introduces genetic variation
(iii) It produces gametes in sexually reproducing organisms
(iv) It produces exact copies of the parent cell
Which are correct?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, meiosis maintains chromosome number across generations, introduces genetic variation through crossing over and independent assortment, and produces gametes. Statement (iv) is incorrect; meiosis does NOT produce exact copies - that is mitosis.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements about telophase is/are correct?
(i) Chromosomes decondense
(ii) Nuclear envelope reforms
(iii) Nucleolus reappears
(iv) Spindle fibres form
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, during telophase: chromosomes decondense back to chromatin, nuclear envelope reforms around each set of chromosomes, and nucleolus reappears. Statement (iv) is incorrect; spindle fibres form during prophase, not telophase. Spindle fibres disassemble during telophase.

questions.question:
Select the correct statements about cytokinesis:
(i) It follows karyokinesis
(ii) In plant cells, it proceeds centripetally
(iii) In animal cells, it proceeds centripetally
(iv) Cell plate formation occurs in plant cells
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (iii), and (iv) are correct. Statement (ii) is incorrect; in plant cells, cytokinesis proceeds centrifugally (from centre outward by cell plate formation). In animal cells, it proceeds centripetally (from periphery inward by cleavage furrow).

questions.question:
How many of the following events occur during prophase of mitosis?
(a) Chromatin condensation (b) Nucleolus disappears (c) Centrioles move to poles (d) Spindle begins to form (e) Centromere splitting (f) Nuclear envelope breaks down
questions.explanation: Events during prophase: (a) chromatin condenses, (b) nucleolus disappears, (c) centrioles move to opposite poles, (d) spindle begins to form, and (f) nuclear envelope breaks down = 5 events. Centromere splitting (e) occurs during anaphase, not prophase.

questions.question:
Consider the following differences between mitosis and meiosis:
(i) Mitosis produces 2 cells, meiosis produces 4 cells
(ii) Mitosis has no crossing over, meiosis has crossing over
(iii) Mitosis occurs in somatic cells, meiosis in germ cells
(iv) Both maintain chromosome number
Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Statement (iv) is incorrect; mitosis maintains chromosome number (equational) while meiosis reduces it to half (reductional).

questions.question:
Which of the following about G0 phase is correct?
(i) Cells in G0 do not divide
(ii) G0 cells are metabolically inactive
(iii) Neurons and RBCs are typically in G0
(iv) G0 cells can re-enter the cell cycle under certain conditions
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, cells in G0 do not divide, neurons and mature RBCs are in G0, and some G0 cells can re-enter the cell cycle when stimulated. Statement (ii) is incorrect; G0 cells are metabolically ACTIVE, they simply do not divide.

questions.question:
Select the correct statement(s) about interkinesis:
(i) It occurs between meiosis I and meiosis II
(ii) DNA replication occurs during interkinesis
(iii) It is generally short-lived
(iv) It is similar to interphase of mitosis
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, interkinesis occurs between meiosis I and II and is short-lived. Statement (ii) is incorrect; NO DNA replication occurs during interkinesis. Statement (iv) is incorrect; interkinesis is NOT the same as interphase since it lacks DNA replication.

questions.question:
Match the phase (Column I) with the event (Column II):
Column I: (a) G1 phase (b) S phase (c) G2 phase (d) M phase
Column II: (i) DNA replication (ii) Cell growth and RNA synthesis (iii) Protein synthesis for division (iv) Nuclear and cytoplasmic division
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: G1 phase involves cell growth and RNA synthesis, S phase involves DNA replication, G2 phase involves protein synthesis for cell division (e.g., tubulin), and M phase involves nuclear and cytoplasmic division.

questions.question:
Match the stage of prophase I (Column I) with its key event (Column II):
Column I: (a) Leptotene (b) Zygotene (c) Pachytene (d) Diplotene
Column II: (i) Synapsis (ii) Crossing over (iii) Chiasmata visible (iv) Chromosome condensation begins
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Leptotene - chromosomes begin to condense, Zygotene - synapsis (pairing of homologous chromosomes), Pachytene - crossing over occurs, Diplotene - chiasmata become visible as homologs begin to separate.

questions.question:
Match the mitotic phase (Column I) with its characteristic (Column II):
Column I: (a) Prophase (b) Metaphase (c) Anaphase (d) Telophase
Column II: (i) Nuclear envelope reappears (ii) Chromosomes condense (iii) Centromere splits (iv) Chromosomes at equatorial plate
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Prophase - chromosomes condense and become visible, Metaphase - chromosomes align at the equatorial plate, Anaphase - centromere splits and chromatids separate, Telophase - nuclear envelope reforms.

questions.question:
Match Column I with Column II:
Column I: (a) Mitosis (b) Meiosis I (c) Meiosis II (d) Amitosis
Column II: (i) Equational, sister chromatids separate (ii) Direct division, no spindle (iii) Equational, 2 identical cells (iv) Reductional, homologs separate
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Mitosis is equational producing 2 identical cells, meiosis I is reductional where homologous chromosomes separate, meiosis II is equational where sister chromatids separate, and amitosis is direct division without spindle formation.

questions.question:
Match the term (Column I) with the definition (Column II):
Column I: (a) Synapsis (b) Bivalent (c) Chiasma (d) Crossing over
Column II: (i) X-shaped structure at point of exchange (ii) Exchange of genetic material between homologs (iii) Paired homologous chromosomes (iv) Pairing of homologous chromosomes
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Synapsis is the pairing of homologous chromosomes, bivalent is a pair of synapsed homologous chromosomes, chiasma is the X-shaped structure at the point of crossing over, and crossing over is the exchange of genetic material between non-sister chromatids.

questions.question:
Match the cell type (Column I) with its division type (Column II):
Column I: (a) Skin cells (b) Germ cells (c) Neurons (d) Liver cells after injury
Column II: (i) Meiosis (ii) G0 (no division) (iii) Mitosis (regular) (iv) Mitosis (stimulated)
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Skin cells undergo regular mitosis for renewal, germ cells undergo meiosis to form gametes, neurons are in G0 (do not divide), and liver cells can be stimulated to undergo mitosis after injury or damage.

questions.question:
Match Column I with Column II regarding DNA content changes:
Column I: (a) G1 phase (b) After S phase (c) After meiosis I (d) After meiosis II
Column II: (i) 2C (ii) 4C (iii) C (iv) 2C
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: In G1, DNA content is 2C (diploid). After S phase (DNA replication), it becomes 4C. After meiosis I, each daughter cell has 2C (still two copies per chromosome). After meiosis II, each cell has C (haploid, one copy).

questions.question:
Match the structure (Column I) with its role in cell division (Column II):
Column I: (a) Centriole (b) Kinetochore (c) Cell plate (d) Cleavage furrow
Column II: (i) Animal cell cytokinesis (ii) Plant cell cytokinesis (iii) Spindle fibre attachment (iv) Organises spindle apparatus
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Centrioles organise the spindle apparatus during cell division, kinetochores are the attachment points for spindle fibres on chromosomes, cell plate forms during plant cell cytokinesis, and cleavage furrow forms during animal cell cytokinesis.

questions.question:
Match Column I with Column II:
Column I: (a) Karyokinesis (b) Cytokinesis (c) Interphase (d) Interkinesis
Column II: (i) Between meiosis I and II (ii) Nuclear division (iii) Cytoplasmic division (iv) G1 + S + G2
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Karyokinesis is nuclear division, cytokinesis is cytoplasmic division, interphase comprises G1 + S + G2 phases, and interkinesis is the brief period between meiosis I and meiosis II.

questions.question:
Match the approximate duration of cell cycle phases in a human cell (24-hour cycle):
Column I: (a) G1 phase (b) S phase (c) G2 phase (d) M phase
Column II: (i) ~6 hours (ii) ~11 hours (iii) ~1 hour (iv) ~4 hours
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, in a typical 24-hour human cell cycle: G1 phase is ~11 hours (longest), S phase is ~6 hours, G2 phase is ~4 hours, and M phase is ~1 hour (shortest).

questions.question:
Match Column I with Column II:
Column I: (a) Independent assortment (b) Crossing over (c) Synapsis (d) Terminalization
Column II: (i) Movement of chiasmata to chromosome ends (ii) Random orientation of bivalents at metaphase I (iii) Exchange between non-sister chromatids (iv) Pairing of homologous chromosomes
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Independent assortment is the random orientation of bivalents at metaphase I, crossing over is exchange between non-sister chromatids, synapsis is pairing of homologous chromosomes during zygotene, and terminalization is movement of chiasmata to chromosome ends during diakinesis.

questions.question:
Match the event (Column I) with the phase of meiosis (Column II):
Column I: (a) Homologous chromosomes at equator (b) Sister chromatids separate (c) Homologous chromosomes separate (d) Chromosomes at equator (single line)
Column II: (i) Anaphase I (ii) Metaphase I (iii) Anaphase II (iv) Metaphase II
questions.explanation: As per NCERT: Bivalents align at the equator during metaphase I, sister chromatids separate during anaphase II, homologous chromosomes separate during anaphase I, and individual chromosomes align at the equator during metaphase II.

questions.question: How many stages are there in prophase I of meiosis?
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, prophase I of meiosis has 5 stages: Leptotene, Zygotene, Pachytene, Diplotene, and Diakinesis. This is the longest and most complex phase of meiosis.

questions.question: If a cell with 2n = 14 undergoes meiosis, how many chromatids will be present during metaphase I?
questions.explanation: At metaphase I, chromosomes are in bivalent form. With 2n = 14, there are 7 bivalents. Each chromosome has 2 chromatids (replicated during S phase), so total chromatids = 14 x 2 = 28 chromatids.

questions.question: If 10 cells undergo meiosis, how many daughter cells will be produced?
questions.explanation: Each cell undergoing meiosis produces 4 haploid daughter cells. Therefore, 10 cells x 4 = 40 daughter cells.

questions.question: How many bivalents will be formed during meiosis in a cell with 2n = 46?
questions.explanation: During meiosis I, homologous chromosomes pair to form bivalents. With 2n = 46 (23 pairs), there will be 23 bivalents (each bivalent = 1 pair of homologous chromosomes = 4 chromatids = tetrad).

questions.question:
How many of the following events are common to both mitosis and meiosis?
(a) Chromosome condensation (b) Spindle formation (c) Crossing over (d) Cytokinesis (e) Synapsis (f) Centromere splitting
questions.explanation: Events common to both mitosis and meiosis: (a) chromosome condensation, (b) spindle formation, (d) cytokinesis, and (f) centromere splitting = 4 events. Crossing over and synapsis are exclusive to meiosis.

questions.question:
Count the total number of phases in the complete cell cycle:
G1, S, G2, Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, Telophase, Cytokinesis
questions.explanation: The complete cell cycle includes 8 distinct phases/stages: G1 phase, S phase, G2 phase (interphase = 3), and Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, Telophase (mitosis = 4), plus Cytokinesis = 3 + 4 + 1 = 8 phases.

questions.question:
How many of the following statements are correct about meiosis II?
(a) It is equational division
(b) Sister chromatids separate
(c) Crossing over occurs
(d) No DNA replication occurs before it
(e) It produces haploid cells
(f) Homologous chromosomes pair
questions.explanation: Correct statements about meiosis II: (a) equational division, (b) sister chromatids separate, (d) no DNA replication before it, and (e) produces haploid cells = 4. Statements (c) and (f) are features of meiosis I, not meiosis II.

questions.question: If a cell has 2n = 8 chromosomes, how many chromosomes will each daughter cell have after mitosis and meiosis respectively?
questions.explanation: After mitosis (equational division), each daughter cell will have the same number as the parent: 8 chromosomes (2n = 8). After meiosis (reductional), each daughter cell will have half: 4 chromosomes (n = 4).

questions.question:
Arrange the stages of prophase I in the correct sequence:
(i) Pachytene
(ii) Diplotene
(iii) Leptotene
(iv) Zygotene
(v) Diakinesis
options: B) i -> ii -> iii -> iv -> v
A) iii -> iv -> i -> ii -> v
C) iii -> i -> iv -> ii -> v
D) iv -> iii -> i -> v -> ii
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the correct sequence of stages in prophase I is: Leptotene -> Zygotene -> Pachytene -> Diplotene -> Diakinesis. A memory aid: 'Lazy Zebras Play During Daytime'.

questions.question:
Arrange the phases of the cell cycle in the correct sequence:
(i) M phase
(ii) S phase
(iii) G1 phase
(iv) G2 phase
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the correct sequence of the cell cycle is: G1 phase (cell growth) -> S phase (DNA synthesis) -> G2 phase (preparation for division) -> M phase (mitosis and cytokinesis).

questions.question:
Arrange the following events of mitosis in the correct chronological order:
(i) Centromere splitting
(ii) Chromosome condensation
(iii) Chromosomes at metaphase plate
(iv) Nuclear envelope reforms
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, the correct order of mitotic events is: Chromosome condensation (prophase) -> Chromosomes at metaphase plate (metaphase) -> Centromere splitting (anaphase) -> Nuclear envelope reforms (telophase).

questions.question:
Arrange the following events of meiosis I in the correct order:
(i) Crossing over at pachytene
(ii) Separation of homologous chromosomes
(iii) Synapsis at zygotene
(iv) Bivalents at equatorial plate
(v) Terminalization of chiasmata
options: B) i -> iii -> iv -> ii -> v
C) iii -> iv -> i -> v -> ii
D) v -> iii -> i -> iv -> ii
A) iii -> i -> v -> iv -> ii
questions.explanation: The correct sequence during meiosis I: Synapsis at zygotene -> Crossing over at pachytene -> Terminalization of chiasmata at diakinesis -> Bivalents at equatorial plate (metaphase I) -> Separation of homologous chromosomes (anaphase I).

questions.question:
Arrange the following in order of decreasing duration in a typical cell cycle:
(i) M phase
(ii) G1 phase
(iii) S phase
(iv) G2 phase
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, in a typical 24-hour cell cycle, the duration in decreasing order is: G1 phase (~11 hours) -> S phase (~6 hours) -> G2 phase (~4 hours) -> M phase (~1 hour).

questions.question:
Arrange the following phases of complete meiosis in order:
(i) Prophase II
(ii) Metaphase I
(iii) Telophase I
(iv) Anaphase II
(v) Prophase I
options: D) ii -> v -> i -> iii -> iv
C) v -> iii -> ii -> iv -> i
A) v -> ii -> iii -> i -> iv
B) i -> ii -> iii -> iv -> v
questions.explanation: The correct sequence of meiotic phases: Prophase I -> Metaphase I -> (Anaphase I -> Telophase I) -> Prophase II -> (Metaphase II -> Anaphase II -> Telophase II). From the given options: Prophase I -> Metaphase I -> Telophase I -> Prophase II -> Anaphase II.

questions.question:
Arrange the following in the correct order of DNA content changes during meiosis (starting from G1):
(i) 2C
(ii) 4C
(iii) 2C
(iv) C
questions.explanation: As per NCERT, DNA content changes during meiosis: 2C (G1) -> 4C (after S phase) -> 2C (after meiosis I, each daughter cell) -> C (after meiosis II, each of 4 cells). This represents the halving of DNA content through two divisions.
